body.value: Okay. So he said, I couldn't use the Scandal Boys and I figured, once we hit the stage there's nothing he can do, it's not like he's going to get on stage, and in the middle of a show, stop and say, hey I told you not to use them. You know I already got half my money, so I don't really care. If you don't give me the rest, that's fine. And so I called that piece pure movement. Because I knew what we did that, I felt that street dance, before it was, again, we we're still calling ourselves street dancers, not hip hop dancers. Street dance was the purest dance vocabulary that there was. There is. And I felt like that for a long long time. Like there was nothing other purer, than a community dance. Dance that come from your community. Without any limitations or philosophies and things put on top of it. And I used to, I'm not an art major, but I took art throughout High School the whole time. So I used to draw and paint and all the stuff, and I still paint, but it's kind of like, so I writing one day, I was writing Rennie Harris, and like doing some graph, is pure movement. And then I realize, I was like oh shit. Harris, the letters I,S, is is. So I don't really need the other is so I just wrote Rennie Harris pure movement.

And I put my name specifically, it was completely vanity, that I put my name on the front of it because in the Scandal boys no one knew who I was. They always say that's the tall guy from the Scandal Boys. And I was the leader. You know when you're a little kids, you're like I'm the leader. You want to be known, that's the tall guy. And I was the choreographer and organizer, and got the gigs and everything. So and, I said, you know what, they're going to know my name. And that's why I put, made it Rennie Harris pure movement at the end. It was completely vain. Like, because I knew the value of branding myself. Because now I can move forward. I couldn't move forward after the Scandal Boys. No one really knew who, unless you knew me as a dancer, you didn't know me. So, if pure movement didn't workout, my name got out there for a couple years.

And then the plan after that became, I told them we have three years. In three years if we don't have a buzz, and we're not touring, the company's not touring, I'm stopping the company. And I told them, I don't want to tour, I've already toured, I already toured around the world a couple times doing hip-hop stuff and I was tired and burned out, and I was like, I don't want to tour. Which turned out to be like, of course, whatever, and I wind up touring for another 20 years. So that's pretty much how it went down far as pure movement was concerned and then, I tried to recruit the best dancers. The best dancers didn't show up for rehearsal. The ones that did challenged me and was like well why do we have to repeat the movement over and over again. We got it. And I said okay do it. And they would mess it up, and I'm like you don't have it. But they don't like the fact that, they wanted me to tell em what the movement is, do it sloppy and that's it.

And that was how we were going to do the performance. And that was traditionally hip-hop. You could just say we can- When we perform I could say to yo, let's do five Steve Martin's go into a Biz Markie and then do some kitten play, and then we'll - I could tell you what we're going to do. And we can do that show right there and be tight. So they're used to that sort of thing, the idea of this is what it's going to be, and it's simple stuff and everyone thinks we practice for years, or whatever. But what I was doing, no, cuz I wanted to do some intricate stuff with street dance. Or was inspired to do it. And that just had, that was a street dance attitude. Always do something different. so when I got challenged, what well this aint really street dance. This aine really hip hop Rennie because you're doing blah blah and it's in a theater, and blah. And I'm like no. It is. But a law, I have to do something different. I have to push the form itself.

You cannot not push the form. You can't get in the circle and do the same movement twice. I can barely wear my clothes twice. I got to change how I wear my clothes in Hip Hop. We can't even say to have the same language in slang if it last more than what a month. I 'll give you one even better. How about one of the biggest hip-hop designers for clothing had to sell the business and go, and then really big, basically went out of business because of hip, the law of hip-hop. He could not make the- Karl Kennie. He could not, he had cross colors. He couldn't make stuff fast enough to keep up with the trend of Hip Hop. Cuz as soon as one thing came in he was going by month to month making new stuff, he didn't have a main line like everybody else the fall line. He had, he couldn't keep up because of the trend of Hip Hop. How fast and progressive the culture moves. So be definition, I'm right on trajectory. With hip hop and theater.

Now I also understand that the resolution that I come up with, some people may not like it. But it is a resolution. And I have three or four of them. And so, the challenge of Academia is right up my alley, like what okay. And the challenge of the theater, and the challenge of my own Community challenging me, is actually the thing that pushes me and I sort of thrive off of it in a way. I don't know if that's good or bad but I did notice that that's you know if it's not me figuring out how to smooth drama out, and point out the obvious and point out what's basic things, what the basic things are. To challenge the conversation. Like so for instance, when I point out certain things in street, the oral history for hip hop, with cats who are at odds.

What happens is I'll say for instance, Boogaloo, the term Boogaloo is, was synonymous with dancing at one point in time. So if you wanted to say hey you Boogaloo, and that meant that you were dancing right. So in the Bay Area challenges, the electric Boogaloo's in regards to Boogaloo Sam saying well I created Boogaloo. And they're saying, well no, you didn't create Boogaloo, we all Boogalooing. But what they're not realizing when I told them, I sat and then mediated a little bit, hew well Boogaloo means dancing so that you know that's what that is, and Sam has redefined it and icon ified it. So he did create the style of Boogaloo, because prior to that it was synonymous with dancing. It wasn't a style. I twas something that you did.

What happens is I'll say for instance, Boogaloo, the term Boogaloo is, was synonymous with dancing at one point in time. So if you wanted to say hey you Boogaloo, and that meant that you were dancing right. So in the Bay Area challenges, the electric Boogaloo's in regards to Boogaloo Sam saying well I created Boogaloo. And they're saying, well no, you didn't create Boogaloo, we all Boogalooing. But what they're not realizing when I told them, I sat and then mediated a little bit, hew well Boogaloo means dancing so that you know that's what that is, and Sam has redefined it and icon ified it. So he did create the style of Boogaloo, because prior to that it was synonymous with dancing. It wasn't a style. I twas something that you did.

So basically the whole point, the whole room just got quiet, for a minute, they looked at Buddha Bonnet, and were like, yeah, but I'm just saying, and he just jumped over the fact of like, no it's this is what it really is. He has codification. It's the Boogaloo road, the Boogaloo hit road. The Boogaloo knee road. A Boogaloo walk out. The twist o flex into a Boogaloo, you know what I mean. Like he has codification. So at the end of the day I feel like I'm keep continue to pick out, point out the obvious in Hip Ho. And point out the obvious in Academia. Because at some point in time you know, I feel like in Academia, it's about numbers right. And it's about education. You going to get some higher education which is great. But also at the end of the day it's about numbers. Can we fill these, can we get these students in here blah blah blah.

What are the things that are going to get the students in here. Well it's relative. What's hot today in this decade. So at some point there's a give and take that Academia has to have in order to get those students. In regards to hip hop in the last 10 years students go into institutions of higher learning expecting that there's a hop hop teacher, who's teaching hip-hop? And then what happens is institution appeases to these students with a local teacher. Which you really can't, as an elective with someone, you can't really get a credit. But the students still not informed enough to go, well hold up, I want to be able to blah blah blah with this because, I've been doing this all my life, I'm 20, I'm 18, 19 years old. And I see the value and the relevance of this. So they're not informed yet mainly because lot of a lot of us have not become bilingual academically in order to speak that language to make the argument. We've needed help from the faculty that was already embedded and sometimes it's just one person and so the progression is slow.
